Memphis is my hometown and Iâ€™ve always had a lot of pride in that... the people, the music, the food, and the culture. But what most DONâ€™T know about this city is that it that sits on top of some of the worldâ€™s cleanest drinking water. It serves over a million local residents. But now that drinking water is at risk because oil companies are planning to build the #ByhaliaPipeline. This pipeline will run through predominantly Black, low-income neighborhoods. This cannot happen. Today, on #EarthDay, please consider what we are doing to the planet AND the people when we destroy sources of clean drinking water simply for the profit of two large companies. Watch to learn more about this and please support the good people of Memphis, by signing the petition in my bio. (Note: the petition is NOT a donation page, just a place to gather signatures to raise awareness on this issue). ğŸ™ğŸ» #MemphisStrong

Celebrating the legacy of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. today â€” and thinking about the message he would have for this country right now, as we countdown to a new administration.

While he spoke about peace and progress - he also talked about responsibility, allyship... and beyond that, real partnership. â€œConstructive social change will bring certain tranquility: evasions will merely encourage turmoil. [The Black community] holds only one key to the double lock of peaceful change. The other is in the hands of the white community.â€ 

We all need to do our part to continue working towards the change that #MLK fought for and was killed for. Because, as he said... there is no other answer.

A few months ago, during lockdown, @antclemons and I wrote a song together called BETTER DAYS. (I actually recorded my final vocals for this song on election night...) â €
â €
This past year brought a lot of frustration, grief, anger â€” and there were times  when it was easy to feel powerless. This song was our way of doing what little we could to encourage everyone to stay hopeful... and keep working towards a better, more equal future. â €
â €
Iâ€™m very honored to announce we will be performing this song on January 20th for the Presidential Inauguration. We have a long way to go to fix, undo, and rebuild this country... but I hope now, despite the past four years, we are on our way. #Inauguration2021

This man was always so kind to me. He had the best stories about legendary moments in @dodgers baseball history and the best stories about life. He had the type of personality that could light up a room â€” and when he spoke, you could hear a pin drop... A true 1 of 1. My stepdad, Paul was always a big fan and on one of his birthdays my good friend @boyfromnewyorkcity helped me surprise him with a dinner with Mr. Lasorda (he insisted I call him Tommy. I still always called him Mr. Lasorda). He shows up at my apartment in NYC and told my stepdad (who was awestruck) all the stories behind their legendary wins and losses, and his amazing career. He stayed far longer than I could ever have asked for and was so happy to be there and put a Cheshire Cat smile on my stepdadâ€™s face. This, maybe the most, spoke to his heart and character because Iâ€™ve heard so many stories like my own about his generosity and humility. â €
â €
This pic is from backstage at SNL on one of the weeks I was hosting. He wanted to come and see me rehearse and in my element and I was truly honored.â €

A real legend and one hell of a man.â €

...a state that happens to be the home of many many confederate monuments. Iâ€™ve been listening closely to the ongoing debates about what to do with these statues â€” and I really want to take a minute to talk about this. â €
â €
When we protest racism in America, people think we are protesting America itself. Why is that the reaction? Because America was built by men who believed in and benefitted from racism. Plain and simple. â €
â €
This is when you hear â€œBut thatâ€™s all in the pastâ€. So letâ€™s be clear... those men who proudly owned and abused Black people are STILL celebrated all over the country. â €
â €
There are roughly 1,848 confederate statues of in the US. More than half are in The South, and itâ€™s not acceptable. No one should be protecting the legacies of confederate leaders and slave owners. 
â €
If we plan to move forward, these monuments must come down. But letâ€™s remember: Removing these statues does not erase our countryâ€™s vile history of oppression â€” removing them is a symbol of respect for Black people in America and itâ€™s a step towards progress and actual equality for all. â €
â €
This video is by @aclu_nationwide, which has been fighting hard to remove these statues across the country. Their Legal Director #JeffreyRobinson has been speaking on this issue for years (you can find more in the link in my bio). Please follow them and learn more about the history of the monuments in your own states and counties.

Boys grow up to be fathers. I think about that a lot these days. We try to teach our son to love and to respect everyone â€” we teach him that all people are all created equal, and that no one should be treated differently because of the color of their skin. We teach him this because one day, he will go on to teach his kids the same. Itâ€™s a cycle. And right now, as we all work to undo generations of discrimination that have plagued our system and our communities across this country... Iâ€™m reminded today that the first lessons start at home. Im grateful for both of my dads and my mother for teaching me those lessons from the beginning. And for listening to me when I had something to say that they hadnâ€™t learned. I pray for that humility with my own son. Iâ€™m grateful for my wife, who made me a father, and is my favorite person/partner/teacher/friend in all of it. Iâ€™m grateful for my son, who is always ALWAYS teaching me right back. â €
â €
Happy Fatherâ€™s Day to all the Dads out there. While we owe our sons and daughters these lessons in the places where the doors close at night, I hope you are as inspired as I am to make them THE TRUTH in the places that same door opens every morning and we send them out to discover. Thereâ€™s more to do. And we are built for it. After all, we are the Dads. Sending my love to you and yours.

We met when we were both teenagers and bonded over our drive and process. I was in awe of what you could do with a basketball and knew your talent went beyond your physical gifts and stretched to your mentality. A mentality that I would take with me throughout my whole career and still use every day. As the years went by, I watched you do things that seemed humanly unimaginable. And, through ups and downs, championships and injuries, you still remained with an unwavering resolve about your mentality to remain fierce to competition. But, every time we would speak or text, something started to change... your patience and ease grew. And it inspired me to continue to grow for myself. Years passed, and the â€œold manâ€ jokes would start to be traded back and forth. We both appreciated a good â€œribbing.â€ We joked about â€œThe Vino Club.â€ You nicknamed yourself â€˜Vinoâ€™ to represent how one could age gracefully as a fine wine does. But, you never stopped aiming to inspire me. Your confidence in me was huge - it really affected me because I admired you so much. I donâ€™t mean as one of the greatest athletes ever. I mean as a person. People sometimes can confuse a will to win with a lack of compassion. That wasnâ€™t you. You had both qualities. The last conversation that we shared was about being fathers and what that meant. That was, beyond all the things that we could do in this world, our true legacy. Who our children are and what beautiful people they will become. And, I guess right now, without being able to find all the words, THAT father connection is what is most devastating for me. I am sending my love to Vanessa and your family and to the families of everyone connected in the mourning of this terrible tragedy. My heart is broken and my family lifts you up in our thoughts and prayers. 
Kobe... You have connected so many of us. The Mamba Mentality will last for all of time. I know that will be a source for me every day as it has been for so many days before. Your legacy is with us. Itâ€™s our responsibility to pass it down now. I hope I can continue to make you proud, Vino. Champ, MVP, Legend, Hero, Inspiration, Father, Friend. Iâ€™m gonna miss you, brother. Mamba forever.

FBF and a MAJOR appreciation and congratulations post to this dynamic duo... Go back to the year 2001 when a young man was stepping out on his own and finding out who he was through his own voice and his own music. These two geniuses not only helped me find my identity but would be mentors and inspirers of my songwriting for years to come and still are some of my favorite collaborators. To P and Chad: you changed my life and will always be two of my heroes. And you are still doing it at that level. Kudos to the @SongwritersHOF for recognizing two artists who changed the landscape of music as we know it. And, congrats to #TheNeptunes!!! No One Ever Really Dies... ğŸ––ğŸ»

First tournament I ever played in... He looked this young man in the eye and introduced himself. You could feel the GREATNESS surrounding him. I was in awe. A few months later, I ran into him on the driving range at Bay Hill with a pitching wedge in my hand and he sat and helped me with my swing (despite his best efforts, I still need all the help I can get...) He changed the game forever. He defined what the modern athlete is. He flew his own plane to his tournaments. He STARTED a network JUST for the sport. He won spectacularly. He lost graciously. He was bigger than the game. And, he was one of the nicest men I have ever met.

I liked the game of golf when I met him. And, HE made me love it. Mr. Palmer, you will be missed by so many avid fans but you will forever be the remembered as THE KING. The definition of a LEGEND.

R.I.P.

Love,

JT

Last night -  in celebration of pride- a group of people - people like you or me or your neighbors or family were dancing & listening to music & celebrating life, just like you or me or your neighbors would. And then, one man and his guns took that life away from them. That's cruel. And it's exactly against what America stands for. I try to make music that hopefully brings joy to people and makes people dance and makes people feel and makes people LOVE... Because there's nothing more pure and beautiful than that act- and the fact that that resulted in the largest mass shooting in American history leaves me heartbroken. I used to LIVE there. I hope we can wake up and realize we are ALL THE SAME. Just humans. One species. Just wanting to be LOVED.

#PrayForOrlando #MoreLoveLessHate

It was Raspberry Beret. I was 4 years old. Yes, 4. I remember that I instantly loved it. "Mommy, who is that singing?" Seems weird but it's true. 
More than a "once in a lifetime" artist... Just a ONCE IN FOREVER ARTIST. I'm still in shock as I write this and I feel this overwhelming grief. But, we should all turn away from that and HONOR this musician that changed all of our lives, our perspectives, our feeling, our whole being. From another planet? Probably. Royalty, for sure. Us worthy..? Laughable.

They say don't meet your idols... That they let you down. But, some of my greatest, funniest (yes, he was hilarious), and most prolific encounters and conversations about music came from the moments that I spent with him. It would be silly to say that he has inspired our music... It's beyond that. He's somewhere within every song I've ever written. 
I am sad, but I will smile when I think of every second that I had the fortune of being in his company. We have lost our greatest living musician. But his music will never die. 
Prince, NOTHING COMPARES...
#RIPPrince

On February 21st, 2010... I had the blessing of meeting and spending time with this man before his show at the Rosemont Theatre in Chicago, IL. He let me photograph him backstage a couple of hours before he went onstage to a beloved crowd and took them to CHURCH. I got him to laugh at a joke at this very moment... My Grandfather was one of his hugest fans, as am I, so this was a very special day for me. The Country Music World has lost a LEGEND and a hell of a man.

#RIPMerleHaggard

Happy Boxing Day! Or as we here in America call it: Steve Zahn Appreciation Day! 
I got to catch up with one of my favorite actors on the latest ep of â€œLife Is Shortâ€ podcast. Steve is one of those actors who is ALWAYS so committed and so interesting to watch, no matter what heâ€™s doing - whether itâ€™s my latest TV obsession â€œWhite Lotusâ€ on @hbomax or the goofy stoner comedy we made â€œStrange Wildernessâ€ many years ago (pic 4 - and yes, I obviously kept the sweater ;)
We talk about how he became an actor, his family life (far from showbiz) on a farm in Kentucky, cracking up with Christian Bale on â€œRescue Dawnâ€, and we reminisce about the old days on and off camera :)
It was just great to catch up with my old friend and have the opportunity to ask him some nerdy fan questions Iâ€™d always been curious about. I hope you all enjoy it! Listen wherever you listen to podcasts! #SteveZahnPahdcast

If I look surprisingly calm in this picture, itâ€™s because I wasâ€¦ kind of. It was taken as we were waiting in between takes and I remember being so drained from the scene, that I was stealing a moment of calm to try and recharge. Gina (Trish) and I had been avoiding meeting or having any contact with the actor playing The Creeper, Jonathan Breck, throughout the entire shoot, in the hopes that itâ€™d be beneficial to all our performances. For six weeks, weâ€™d been avoiding running into each other - which wasnâ€™t an easy feat on a lower budget movie, shooting in a somewhat remote part of Florida and starring only a handful of actors. If Jonathan was coming to get his lunch at catering, we were quickly shepherded away - if he was in the makeup trailer getting ready, weâ€™d wait somewhere else - and vice versa. When we were shooting the above scene, on our last day of working together, the mechanisms on his face wing things (?) werenâ€™t opening properly and it required several extra takes of this shot where Iâ€™m supposed to be as scared as humanly possible. Eventually, I got so tired and it was easier for the crew, trying to get the shot, if I just waited there (rather than walking away to preserve whatever was left of the illusion that weâ€™d spent so long cultivating). Jonathan could tell I was wiped out (I think I even started resting my head gently on his arm that stayed loosely wrapped around my neck) and, at one point, a kind, slightly twangy voice came from inside that hideously sinister face: â€œYou doinâ€™ alright?â€
But I didnâ€™t answer. Either Iâ€™d gotten so used to not talking to him or I was still trying desperately to pretend he was a monster haha. Or both? I donâ€™t think, looking back, any of those games or tricks made it a better performance - it was probably a total waste of energy and time. But you live and learn and Iâ€™m so grateful for all Iâ€™ve gotten to liveâ€¦ and continue to learnâ€¦

As a gift for being understandable about the casting snafu (I think), he sent me this ğŸ‘†- autographs of some of his most iconic characters, written in their distinct handwriting. Itâ€™s been seven years since Phil passed away. Years before that, in the early 2000â€™s, we were in a crowded restaurant (El Compadre on Sunset Blvd) and Phil was telling a really funny story about an embarrassing thing that had happened to him. Rather than lean in and whisper the most embarrassing part to us, so as to spare himself the shame of onlookers judgement, he stood up from the table and committed to a full-body mime of it, while laughing his great big wheezy laugh. As funny as it was, I immediately became a little self conscious on his behalf and looked around the restaurant to see peopleâ€™s reactions. Phil was an acting god to me so I just assumed everyone recognized him but even if they didnâ€™t, they were now staring at him - he was laughing so hard his face had turned pink and his eyes were watering. But what struck me most about Phil, in that moment, was how unaware he was of anything outside the story he was telling and the people he was telling it to - he lived that moment the way he lived every moment as an actor: fully present and committed and without a hint of self consciousness. It was beautiful - something Iâ€™ll never forget and always aspire to. 
I canâ€™t wait to have another night out with friends at a place like El Compadre, telling stories and laughing - but I donâ€™t think Iâ€™ll ever have a night quite like that one, because nobody tells stories or laughs with quite as much abandon as Phil did ğŸ˜Œâ¤ï¸

When I got to work with Alan Rickman on â€œGalaxy Questâ€, I was a VERY wide-eyed young actor doing my very first movie. It spoiled me. It gave me the false impression that all great actors were like Alan. He treated everyone the same. He always sat and ate his lunch with the crew. Heâ€™d stay and do off-camera for the other actors even if he was just giving them â€œa lookâ€ in the scene. He was equally generous with his downtime, letting me and Jeremy Howard pick his brain like hungry young acting vultures. He had an unbelievably funny and dark sense of humor but his delivery was often so dry that if you werenâ€™t present enough to catch his subtle rhythms or the faint mischievous gleam in his eye, you might think he was being a stuffy misanthrope. The thing that amazed me most about him was that, in those instances, heâ€™d never make it clear he WAS joking! It was something that required real social courage and a commitment that I doubt Iâ€™ll ever possess but will always aspire to. I saw this happen to a few high-powered executives that sat down at lunch to put in some time with him (while ignoring other â€œlower statusâ€ people at the table). When they got up to leave, a little weirded out and uncomfortable, Alan gave me a sly knowing grin. I loved that moment - I loved others that I donâ€™t remember as well. I loved him. This is a picture from the wrap party where Alan, this classically trained master British thespian, partied so much harder than anyone else. He passed away 5 years ago today. I didnâ€™t know him well but  I still think about him all the time. 
I did a play, years later, that he had been doing for many months and had just voluntarily left, replaced by another actor. But he still came to see me in my opening night. He left flowers and a card with a message inside that still makes me smile so big. On the front of the card was a beautiful sunset with fancy font cursive letters that just said â€œFuck Youâ€ ğŸ˜Œ #tbt

Me and my first dog, Moose. He was as disobedient and horny as he was adorable... and I loved him (most of the time). 

One day, when he was playing in the yard belonging to the family of my girlfriend (at the time), he disappeared.  Her other dogs remained but Moose was nowhere to be found. Panicked, we ran around her neighborhood (between Koreatown and Hancock Park in LA) scouring the streets and yards. Nothing. We put up signs offering a substantial reward (probably too substantial, in retrospect, but we were desperate and not thinking clearly). The next day I got a call from a man who said theyâ€™d found our dog. I had just started to eagerly thank him when he interrupted me to coldly ask â€œSo, can I get that reward money in cash?â€ In my excited relief, Iâ€™d forgotten about the reward and, more importantly, how substantial weâ€™d made it. Red flags went off by how blunt and inconsiderate his tone was. I told him I could get half in cash and would he accept the rest in check form. â€œUh... no, itâ€™s gonna have to be all cashâ€, he responded. More red flags. I couldâ€™ve opened a whole red flag store, if that werenâ€™t too niche a thing and not at-all sustainable from a business perspective. I agreed to get him cash and we set a time to meet up....

Some â€œCrossroadsâ€ memories...
I remember being slightly nervous to work with Britney Spears - she was such a massive star in 2002 (as she still is). When she introduced herself to me in the makeup trailer, I was disarmed by how sweet and NOT famous she seemed - just a nice girl (not yet a woman) from Louisiana. She immediately made me feel comfortable, as did Tamra Davis (the director) and @shondarhimes (the writer - p.s. what ever happened to HER???) and, despite having a small part, I felt encouraged to play around and improvise a bit - such a great working environment (they even let me blatantly rip off one of my favorite scenes from â€œTake the money and Runâ€). I was also excited to work with Eric Edwards who shot some of my favorite Gus Van Sant movies like â€œMy Own Private Idahoâ€ and â€œTo Die Forâ€ (we worked together again a few years later on â€œThe Breakupâ€) 
Britney seemed to get exponentially more tense (totally understandably) whenever we walked off set with her bodyguard â€œBig somethingâ€ (my memory is so bad but I remember really liking him - a massive, warm, friendly, terrifying guy). People would clamor to get to her and paparazzi were constantly lurking behind trees, in bushes, etc. 
Years later, when the tabloid frenzy surrounding Britney reached a fever pitch, I remember feeling so sorry for her. Nobody deserves to be hounded and harassed like that - least of all a very sweet person - one who behaved kindly towards a young nervous actor who occupied a much lower rung on the hierarchical ladder of that film set. 
I also loved the casting directors @kimdaviswag + @justinearteta so much. Justine was such a present + connected reader, sheâ€™d make it so much easier to be present and connected yourself. 
When I saw the movie, I remember thinking that it looked like I was wearing pantyhose on my head because the makeup people only put makeup on my pasty white face and failed to cover up the rest of my translucent body (probably because it wouldâ€™ve gotten all over the sheetsğŸ¤¢). Though I personally think it makes Britneyâ€™s skin tone look that much nicer - and she was the star, after all, despite not acting like one :) #tbt

I was lucky enough to spend some time working at a camp like @okizu, a camp for kids with cancer and the families struggling to keep them alive and happy (@campboggycreek in Eustis, FL). I can tell you how transformative that one week is for kids and for the counselors - getting to see kids stricken with a life-threatening illness (who normally spend all day in hospitals, hooked up to machines or hearing worried conversations between parents) just get to be kids and do fun stuff with other kids, out in nature, briefly forgetting problems that most of us adults never have to deal with. Itâ€™s amazing how important that one week is for these kids, how much more it is than just â€œcampâ€ and it really breaks my heart that these fires took THAT from them. So for the next couple weeks, if you want to â€œhireâ€ me on @cameo, all my $ will go there, to help rebuild. And if thatâ€™s not your thing and you have a few dollars you can spare, check out @okizu or follow the link in my bio. Thanks!

ğŸ¶ This is the Tom Green post, itâ€™s not the green Tom post! ğŸ¶ 
If you didnâ€™t watch MTV in the 90â€™s, you may have just thought I had a mild stroke - But if you DID, like my friends and I did growing up, then @tomgreen may also have been a big part of your comedic coming-of-age. Tomâ€™s humor was brand new to me, at the time. It had roots in Monty Python and The Kids in The Hall -but the concept of interacting directly with people on the street, and creating hilarious chaos from everyday scenarios, THAT was new to me - and exciting and SO funny and, looking back, groundbreaking. Tom was kind enough to sit for a zoom with me where we talked about his own comedic evolution, the well-documented pranks heâ€™d play on his parents, his (also well-documented) battle w cancer, his foray into the early days of podcasting and his regrets, his hopes, his mild annoyances. I really loved talking to him - I hope you all enjoy it too! You can listen to â€œLife is Shortâ€ podcast wherever you listen to podcasts - probably on the device youâ€™re currently looking at :)

Madre Albertinaâ€™s Girls Home in Granada, Nicaragua (the 2nd poorest country in Latin America) is a rare and vital haven for more than 50 social orphans to SAFELY get an education, proper nutrition, and a chance to realize their full potential. Our guest on the latest â€œLife is Shortâ€ podcast is my old high school friend and former #1 ranked US menâ€™s tennis ace, James Blake. James and I reminisce about Ms Dewittâ€™s math class, his thrilling US Open match against Andre Agassi, and, most importantly and timely, his own encounter with racially-motivated police brutality. In 2015, while waiting for a car to pick him up en route to a US Open event, James was standing outside his hotel in New York City when a member of the NYPD (in plain clothes) tackled him to the ground, put his knee in Jamesâ€™ back, handcuffed him and interrogated him right there for all to see. As EVERYONE now knows, the situation couldâ€™ve been gravely worse - James was lucky. And weâ€™re lucky to have him as our guest today to help us have this vital conversation about race, the need for police oversight and transparency, and, more superficially, just to catch up and reminisce. Iâ€™ve always admired my friend for his humor, positivity and enviable athletic skills (especially since I have the tennis prowess of a toddler)- after hearing his story of determination in the face of a system that is rigged against him, I now admire him for SO so much more. Dear instafriends, 
Around this time each week, I post about a new episode of our podcast but I thought Iâ€™d share with you some other podcasts that Iâ€™ve been enjoying lately. *We love doing the podcast more than anything and are truly grateful to everyone who tunes in. 1. Code Switch...

3. Good Ancestor...

How can I create a legacy of healing and liberation for those who are here in this lifetime and those who will come after Iâ€™m gone?â€ Sheâ€™s driven by this question and her passion and curiosity are infectious. When people tell me they like â€œStrange Wildernessâ€ (a critically panned movie that tanked when it was released 12 years ago) it immediately makes me happy. Maybe because I also like dumb stoner comedies. Maybe because it lets me know that the person Iâ€™m talking to doesnâ€™t take themselves or their taste in movies too seriously. Or maybe because Iâ€™m transported back to the carefree, enjoyable experience of shooting that movie. Jonah and I were roommates at the time and weâ€™d carpool to set together. We were both playing outrageous characters that we were given a lot of freedom with. I loved the smart stupidity of the script and had desperately wanted to work with Steve Zahn, one of my favorite actors. And the rest of the cast was terrific and so game. I think we all felt lucky to share scenes with the sweet, gentle legend, Earnest Borgnine (who I still canâ€™t believe agreed to do the movie). There were so many moments throughout the day when the toughest acting challenge became not laughing during a take. Normally you know when a take has gone off the rails and is basically unusable, so laughing doesnâ€™t really ruin anything - but this movie was so weird and unhinged that everything was in play - we were encouraged to act like the biggest idiots possible. It was a dream job. On the drive home, Jonah and I would usually still be laughing at something that happened on set or weâ€™d listen to music, too tired from the dayâ€™s fun to laugh anymore. It was the best. Lately Iâ€™ve been feeling so grateful that I get to do what I do as a job. But some jobs Iâ€™m EXTRA grateful for and the box office receipts or rotten tomato score never really have anything to do with it #tbt ğŸ˜ŒâœŒï¸ğŸ’¨

In 1994 I was a wide-eyed teenager whoâ€™d just fallen head over heels in love with movies and the prospect of one day making a movie, when I saw â€œClerksâ€ - a movie that was basically about a convenience store clerk who had to go to work when he didnâ€™t want to. It was hilarious and moving and all the things my favorite movies were AND, most importantly, it looked like it was made for the same amount of money I could MAYBE scrounge together (because it was). It made the idea of making movies or being in them instantly accessible - no longer a shameful little pipe dream I had but a potentially achievable goal. Years later the director of that movie would take me under his creative wing in a more direct way, putting me in several of his projects - the most formative and meaningful one being an insane experimental Human Centipede-esque romp called â€œTuskâ€ and I am forever changed because of it (in a MUCH more positive way than my character in that movie). @thatkevinsmith is our guest on todayâ€™s episode of â€œLife Is Shortâ€. We talk about our experience working with one another and Kevin drops some beautifully articulate pearls about life, his creative history, and his very recent brush with death. It has been an honor to work with him over the years and, if nothing else, Iâ€™m always grateful to have the opportunity to thank him for always inviting me to play in his fun, weird sandbox. Hope you guyâ€™s enjoy this episode (link in bio) - itâ€™s a little longer than usual but Kevin is just too good at talking. ğŸ˜˜

One of my favorite animals as a kid was the red-spotted newt. As an adult, I now feel very lucky to live in a place where theyâ€™re found in abundance in the wild. Unlike most amphibians, though, the Red-spotted newt has a sort of adolescent stage where they live on land for 2-3 years and are called â€œeftsâ€ by humans but probably normal names like â€œCarlâ€ and â€œStacyâ€ by other efts. When theyâ€™re ready to become adults and have kids of their own, they return to the water, their skin becomes a drab olive-green and they get all slimy and THEN start making love. From THE GREAT BEANIE FELDSTEIN BAT MITZVAH OF â€˜07. @jonahhill @poodollar72 me + @jontogo all bear witness to Jonahâ€™s funny, talented, sweet kid sister @beaniefeldstein becoming a woman.  This weekend EVERYONE will bear witness to Beanie becoming a movie star in @oliviawildeâ€™s future classic @booksmart. Go see it!

#tbt #for #the PODCAST listeners...
In the last episode (w @oliviawilde), thereâ€™s a story about my high school yearbook photo which, as discussed, is far more embarrassing than the regular embarrassing yearbook photo. The FIRST photo is the one my mother made me retake (at an extra cost, of course) because she (my own mother) was TOO EMBARRASSED TO FRAME THE OTHER ONE AND DISPLAY IT IN THE HOUSE. (As was I, so Iâ€™m grateful she went along with it.)
The second picture, for you podcast listeners, needs no further elaboration. Youâ€™re welcome and as therapeutic as this has all been, thereâ€™s a part of me that still canâ€™t quite believe Iâ€™m voluntarily sharing this with more people...

1. Years ago my dear funny friend @oliviawilde asked me to play a part in her first short film â€œFree Hugsâ€. I knew then that one day sheâ€™d direct a great feature - I just didnâ€™t know itâ€™d be AS great as #booksmartmovie is. Iâ€™m insanely proud of her and grateful she sat down to talk to me about her new movie, her old name + many things in between on this weekâ€™s episode of â€œLife Is Shortâ€ - listen by following the link in my bio! #FemaleFilmmakerTuesday
2. â€œFree Hugsâ€ group shot (I played a cross-eyed store clerk with a wispy mustache and an underbite named â€œGerryâ€)
3. Olivia was actively involved in every aspect of the shoot (but did so respectfully without stepping on toes - quite a feat). Here she is applying makeup to an actor. 
4. Everyone liked her on set. Oftentimes background actors (or â€œextrasâ€) get overlooked or dismissed - here she is directing some of them. Olivia treated everyone with respect. 
5. â€œThrilledâ€ to be at the Jets game. Not sure what year this was but, knowing the Jets, it couldâ€™ve been anytime in the last 5 decades. 
6. Olivia introduced me to political activism and Honey Badger videos in 2007. 
7. Goofing around with Sam Rockwell and Jeremy Renner. Go see #booksmartmovie this Friday May 24th - itâ€™s easily my favorite movie of the year!
